rev.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/Pacorro55|Pacorro55]] ([[User talk:Pacorro55|talk]]) to last version by Michaelas10
rev.diff:
Line 16: Line 16:
'''Google Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}} and {{lse|GGEA}}) is a [[United States|U.S.]] [[public company|public corporation]], first [[Incorporation (business)|incorporated]] as a [[Privately held company|privately held corporation]] the [[7 September]] [[1998]], that designs and manages the [[Internet]]'s most used [[search engine]]. The company employs approximately 8,000 employees and is based in [[Mountain View, California]]. [[Eric E. Schmidt|Eric Schmidt]], former [[chief executive officer]] of [[Novell]], was named Google's CEO when co-founder [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] stepped down.
'''Google Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}} and {{lse|GGEA}}) is a [[United States|U.S.]] [[public company|public corporation]], first [[Incorporation (business)|incorporated]] as a [[Privately held company|privately held corporation]] the [[7 September]] [[1998]], that designs and manages the [[Internet]]'s most used [[search engine]]. The company employs approximately 8,000 employees and is based in [[Mountain View, California]]. [[Eric E. Schmidt|Eric Schmidt]], former [[chief executive officer]] of [[Novell]], was named Google's CEO when co-founder [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] stepped down.
â
The name "Google" originated from a misspelling of "[[googol]],"<ref>Koller, David. "[http://graphics.stanford.edu/~dk/google_name_origin.html Origin of the name, "Google."] ''[[Stanford University]].'' January, 2004.</ref><ref>Hanley, Rachael. "[http://daily.stanford.org/article/2003/2/12/fromGoogolToGoogle From Googol to Google: Co-founder returns]." ''[[The Stanford Daily]].'' [[February 12]], [[2003]]. Retrieved on [[July 14]], [[2006]].</ref> which refers to 10<sup>100</sup> (a 1 followed by one-hundred zeros). Google has had a major impact on online culture. The verb "[[Google (verb)|google]]" was recently added to both the ''[[Merriam Webster|Merriam Webster Collegiate Dictionary]]'' and the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'', meaning "to use the Google search engine to obtain information on the Internet."<ref>Harris, Scott D. "[http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/business/14985574.htm Dictionary adds verb: to google]." ''[[San Jose Mercury News]].'' [[July 7]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[July 7]], [[2006]].</ref><ref>Bylund, Anders. "[http://www.joseramonsanchez.com/ To Google or Not to Google]." ''[[The Motley Fool]] via [[MSNBC]].'' [[July 5]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[July 7]], [[2006]].</ref>
+
The name "Google" originated from a misspelling of "[[googol]],"<ref>Koller, David. "[http://graphics.stanford.edu/~dk/google_name_origin.html Origin of the name, "Google."] ''[[Stanford University]].'' January, 2004.</ref><ref>Hanley, Rachael. "[http://daily.stanford.org/article/2003/2/12/fromGoogolToGoogle From Googol to Google: Co-founder returns]." ''[[The Stanford Daily]].'' [[February 12]], [[2003]]. Retrieved on [[July 14]], [[2006]].</ref> which refers to 10<sup>100</sup> (a 1 followed by one-hundred zeros). Google has had a major impact on online culture. The verb "[[Google (verb)|google]]" was recently added to both the ''[[Merriam Webster|Merriam Webster Collegiate Dictionary]]'' and the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'', meaning "to use the Google search engine to obtain information on the Internet."<ref>Harris, Scott D. "[http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/business/14985574.htm Dictionary adds verb: to google]." ''[[San Jose Mercury News]].'' [[July 7]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[July 7]], [[2006]].</ref><ref>Bylund, Anders. "[http://msnbc.msn.com/id/13720643/ To Google or Not to Google]." ''[[The Motley Fool]] via [[MSNBC]].'' [[July 5]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[July 7]], [[2006]].</ref>
Google's services are run on several [[server farm]]s, each consisting of thousands of low-cost commodity computers running stripped-down versions of [[Linux]]. While the company does not provide detailed information about its hardware, a 2006 estimate consisted of over 450,000 servers, racked up in clusters located in data centers around the world (See [[Google platform]] for more details on their technology).<ref name="howgoogleworks">Carr, David F. "[http://www.baselinemag.com/print_article2/0,1217,a=182560,00.asp How Google Works]." ''[http://www.baselinemag.com/ Baseline Magazine].'' [[July 6]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[July 10]], [[2006]].</ref> According to the Nielsen cabinet, Google is the most popular [[search engine]] on the web with a 54% market share, ahead of [[Yahoo!]] (23%) and [[MSN]] (13%). It receives about a billion search requests per day, which are recorded and stored indefinitely "to improve its search engines."<ref> {{fr}} {{cite news | title=Google se plie Ã  la censure de PÃ©kin pour percer sur le marchÃ© de l'Internet chinois | publisher=Le Monde | date=January 26, 2006 | url=http://www.lemonde.fr/web/article/0,1-0@2-651865,36-734719,0.html}} </ref>
Google's services are run on several [[server farm]]s, each consisting of thousands of low-cost commodity computers running stripped-down versions of [[Linux]]. While the company does not provide detailed information about its hardware, a 2006 estimate consisted of over 450,000 servers, racked up in clusters located in data centers around the world (See [[Google platform]] for more details on their technology).<ref name="howgoogleworks">Carr, David F. "[http://www.baselinemag.com/print_article2/0,1217,a=182560,00.asp How Google Works]." ''[http://www.baselinemag.com/ Baseline Magazine].'' [[July 6]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[July 10]], [[2006]].</ref> According to the Nielsen cabinet, Google is the most popular [[search engine]] on the web with a 54% market share, ahead of [[Yahoo!]] (23%) and [[MSN]] (13%). It receives about a billion search requests per day, which are recorded and stored indefinitely "to improve its search engines."<ref> {{fr}} {{cite news | title=Google se plie Ã  la censure de PÃ©kin pour percer sur le marchÃ© de l'Internet chinois | publisher=Le Monde | date=January 26, 2006 | url=http://www.lemonde.fr/web/article/0,1-0@2-651865,36-734719,0.html}} </ref>
